AI cannot replace a human worker by doing the exact same work as a human would do, but it can make workers more productive by helping with some tasks, and effectively so, reduce the staffing needs. Basically companies can fire half the employees if AI can help the remaining half to do twice as much work.The other aspect is that management believes AI to replace human workers and uses this as an argument to cut payroll budgets and layoff people, while expecting the remaining lucky survivors to work twice as hard to fulfill the promised efficiency gains.

To be honest, digital jobs are a lot easier to be replaced by a digital AI than physical jobs being replaced by AI powered robots, due to the high cost of building robots. So I think plenty of labor jobs like plumbing or construction or gardening (etc) aren't going to be replaced by millions of robots any time soon.

Here you have the course structure.To clarify I am a student in a big confusion, which would like to do a master degree in AI(or maybe other related fields) for passion of learning inovative techs and aiming for a better career that I would have just as a web dev.As well feedback from people which finished a master in AI is highly appreciated.​* **Legal, Ethical & Professional Issues (10 Credits)**This class ensures students are aware of the legal, social, ethical and professional issues commensurate with the practice of AI as well as, more broadly, information and data science.* **Quantitative Methods for AI (10 Credits)**Quantitative methods such as linear algebra, probability, statistics, and calculus are needed to understand AI and to keep pace with its development. This course gives students the background in these topics they need.* **Big Data Technologies (20 Credits)**This course gives students an understanding of the challenges posed by big data, an understanding of the key algorithms and techniques which are embodied in data analytics, and exposure to a number of different big data technologies and techniques.* **AI for Autonomous Systems (20 credits)**This course covers gives a basic introduction to AI including topics such as intelligent search.* **Deep Learning & Neural Nets (20 Credits)**The most impactful area of AI has been machine learning using neural networks. When combined with reinforcement learning, these neural networks can also become autonomous agents that can, for example, learn to play games to an extraordinarily high standard. This class will cover these two areas of AI.* **AI for Finance (20 credits)**This class provides an overview of the application of AI techniques -- including those which mimic natural evolutionary processes (genetic algorithms and genetic programming in particular) to a range of financial applications such as forecasting, portfolio optimisation and algorithmic trading.* **Machine Learning for Data Analytics (20 credits)**This class equips students with a sound understanding of the principles of machine learning and a range of popular approaches, along with the knowledge of how and when to apply the techniques.

AI will reshape the workforce, but a one-to-one replacement of human jobs? Not so fast.Yes, the technology exists to automate many tasks. But history shows that how we implement AI matters just as much as what we automate.Economists like Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo have long studied the right vs. wrong kinds of AI adoption. The wrong kind? Automation that replaces workers outright. The right kind? AI that augments human potential, creating new roles and opportunities.The real question isnt if AI will replace jobsits how we shape the future of work. Companies that get this right will drive innovation without eroding the workforce.How do you see AI changing jobs in the next 5-10 years?

>2) if it doesnt, it means the economy is so wrecked that were on our way to total collapse or UBI anywaysNot sure about that. We're talking about a single class of people: white-collar knowledge workers.If there are no more white-collar jobs, this means radical change, but not necessarily UBI for them, or the end of work altogether.We still need plumbers, construction workers, factory line workers, surgeons, nurses, etc. There's a lot of jobs that won't be replaced by AI. Generally, we're talking about jobs that are closer to the physical realm of things. And as much as AI will definitely accelerate to levels we can't totally comprehend at the moment, there's no sign (yet) that robotics will accelerate with it. And even if it did, building a robotics industry to replace physical workers takes a lot of time, as it requires a huge time and labor investment on physical things, from resource extraction to labor. There might be a lot of people having to switch careers in the next 10 years, but I'd bet that's mostly us white-collar knowledge workers. Maybe we'll have people moving from software engineering to paramedics; from administrative assistant to factory line worker.Yes, the white collar middle class might end completely. I don't like it. I'm part of it. And one of the factors that will play a huge part in this is the fact that we're total pussies: there will be no revolution by us, and we'll passively accept whatever outcomes are offered us. So yeah, in theory we're fucked when it comes to jobs. But we're not everyone.On the other hand, I believe that by the time we start being replaced by AIs, we'll be much more concerned with other things, such as an actual existential risk to humans as a whole. Who cares about jobs if an AGI is building biological organisms to kill us all?

Which jobs will definitely not be replaced by AI?

Long term, it's only going to be jobs where even if an AI could technically do it better, we'd still prefer it be done by a human, at least some of the time. I think there are a few main categories: 1) Jobs involving leadership and power. We're going to value human leadership for the foreseeable future.2) Endeavors that require a cathartic, human connection. This includes certain kinds of art, comedy and entertainment. It also includes at least some forms of therapy/counseling. Weirdly, it also includes influencers and other personalities.3) Roles where a person is providing something integral to the experience. Think waiters/hosts/servers in restaurants. Or messeuses, or operators of treatments in spas. And on a darker note, that includes providers of other forms of sensual contact or content.For example, I probably don't care whether a human or a robot cuts my grass or fixes my plumbing. But I'd want my mayor to be human. I care if my art was made with human yearning and fallibility. Some therapy requires a human connection. And the restaurant without servers would be much like just getting takeout.Even in the above roles, AI will definitely take many of the jobs.

I think that threshold will be constantly rising, probably quite rapidly. Initially you wont need junior developers because a senior developer could churn through work by setting AI to do a lot of the grunt work and using his/her experience to put the pieces together. During that time the senior developer who can use AI will would probably see somewhat higher salaries. We are pretty much already at this point in many companies.But AI is constantly improving and all the higher level work the senior devs are doing to correct, improve on, or aggregate what the AI produces becomes training data for the next generation of AIs. Very soon, the threshold has risen past the senior developer and their salaries have tanked. Then maybe you just need a principal engineer or architect who can sketch out the pieces needed for a large scale system and AI can take it from there. Soon after that, you only need someone to describe a proposed software product in general terms and the AI will be able to architect the large scale system, break it down into modular services, and write those services. The threshold will rise constantly and very rapidly.EDIT: typos fixed

You say AI then talk about automation. Not really the same thing automation has been removing the need for humans doing tasks for hundreds of years. Home automation like washing machines, dishwashers etc; factory automation has been massive in the last 50 years. AI though is mostly threatening menial language based jobs like web content creation and to a lesser degree artistic jobs. This is because of how ChatGPT etc work, theyre language based. Yeah they can start to do some more advanced tasks like basic programming (again language related) but they do an extremely poor job and writing code is only like 30% of a programmers job. Its not really threatening anything there but is a tool that can be leveraged. The idea that AI will take over all jobs including physical oriented ones Id just ridiculous to me. I worked at a company that did ML sentiment analysis a while back and its really hard to train a model on something and have the results be accurate, especially where there is a lot of nuance. Yes since that era things have gotten better but you still need massive training sets and you train it to do specific things. They really are not smart at all. Its bs hype to get VC funding.

Hey People,I've seen a lot of anxiety lately about AI taking over our jobs. But let's be real, AI isn't the enemy - it's a tool, and like any tool, it's only as good as the person wielding it.Think about it: content writers who know how to use AI-powered research tools and language generators can produce high-quality content faster and more efficiently than ever before. Web developers who can harness the power of machine learning can build websites that are more intuitive and user-friendly. And data analysts who can work with AI to identify patterns and trends can make predictions and decisions that were previously impossible.The point is, AI isn't here to replace us - it's here to augment us. It's here to make us faster, smarter, and more productive. So, instead of fearing the robots, let's learn how to work with them. Let's upskill and reskill, and become the masters of our own AI-powered destinies.Remember, it's not the AI that's going to take your job - it's the person who knows how to use AI to do your job better, faster, and cheaper.

Its no secret that AI is becoming a bigger part of the hiring processbut lately, its presence is becoming very obvious.Take this recent experience: A candidates resume looked almost too perfectevery skill, every experience, a flawless match. But during the screening call, things got interesting. When asked about their experience, they simply read through the job description and claimed they could do everything on itwithout giving a single real-world example.It just so happens this person had just finished a course in "AI Management" as well Was I being too sceptical? Was this person potentially JUST AMAZING? Or did I make the right callAI can make recruitment more efficient, but its also creating new challenges. As hiring professionals, our ability to dig deeper, ask the right questions, and assess real expertise is more important than ever.Have you noticed similar patterns in your areas of expertise? As a ProcessAgilist, automating workflow using AI, I'm frequently confronted with the question: Doesn't automation lead to "job loss"? Isn't someone going be fired because of you? How can you live with yourself? Aren't we just automating jobs away?That's a tough one, and I get it. If you've made your money a certain way for a while, disruptive technology... well... Disrupts!Automation changes the way we work, no doubt about it. It often makes certain roles obsolete. History has repeatedly shown us that when a door closes, a window opensoften to a room with a much broader view. Remember the Pony Express? Revolutionary in its day, yet it couldn't outpace the advent of the telegraph. And look at us now, communicating across the globe in an instant on LinkedIn. Gone are the days of milling flour by hand, and your daily bread we're all so thankful for, is within easier reach for everyone due to automation.My job isn't to replace people with machines; it's to find ways to let machines do the repetitive, boring, tedious stuff so that people can focus on what they're best at solving real problems, being creative, creating genuine connections.The way I see it, I help people transition from one opportunity to the next, upping their game in a world where change is the only constant.Sure, it's challenging, but it's also exciting. We're not just workers; we're learners and innovators. And if history's shown us anything, it's that, as a species, we're pretty good at adapting.If you're not part of the automation process, you will certainly be disrupted BY it. Learn the trade being created by the automation, rather than defending the trade supplanted by it. The microwave has saved countless hours of toil. Restaurants learned to harness the power of microwave technology to make better food faster, rather than trying to outlaw them. Not all food comes out quite right when microwaved... and not every job can be replaced by AI... but the jobs will surely change. People won't be directly replaced by AI, but those who know how to use it will surely replace those who don't.Lets not fear automation. Let's use it as a tool to create a future where work is more about what we bring to the table as humans creativity, empathy, innovation. Recognize how AI impacts your profession so you can shape that future rather than become a victim of it. Become the first tailor to master the sewing machine. Let's brainstorm that future together to make it one we're proud of.

The best feature of AI is that we won't ever be forced to deal with people.If you ever tried to rationally communicate anything to those creatures, you'll know why.Ask any waiter, sales clerk or phone support worker.​We.do.not.argue.with.idiots.

Some bubble bursting of hashtag#LLMs is already happening.Story 1:I have a contact who works at a firm (which shall remain unnamed) that provides copy editing services in English.For the last couple of years, they employed a large team of AI engineers and data scientists. The goal was to use as much AI as possible to do the copy editing, in other words, reduce the reliance on humans to do copy editing (I'm, of course, euphamising ).After two years, and a huge amount of money spent, they finally deployed it into production. They soon realized that it wasn't good enough, and everything the AI did finally had to be double checked and corrected by a human. Essentially, the time taken by the human to check and correct the output was the same as if the human had done it from start to finish without any AI help.They disbanded their (by now quite large) AI/DS team, and decommissioned the platform they had built. They went back to humans doing what they were doing, the old school way.Story 2:A rich law firm (which, again, shall remain unnamed) that a contact works in also tried to do similar things to replace paralegals. They employed a large number of highly paid AI engineers/Data scientists to create something that could reduce their paralegal costs (aka help make some paralegal staff redundant and still do the job). After a lot of time and money, they found the solution unreliable, and went back to the old way.P.S. - Some additional context on the copy editing story. I was quite surprised by what my contact said, and asked why it was the case when grammar checkers are really quite good these days. My contact explained to me was that copy-editing involves more than just grammar correction. If grammar correction was all that was needed, spelling and grammar checkers would have replaced copy editors years, if not a decade, ago.

tl;dr: by the time a problem is articulated well enough to be viable for something like SWE-bench, as a senior engineer, I basically consider the problem solved. What SWE-bench measures is not a relevant metric for my job.note: I'm not saying it won't happen, so please don't misconstrue me (see last paragraph). But I think SWE-bench is a misleading metric that's confusing the conversation for those outside the field.An anecdote: when I was a new junior dev, I did a lot of contract work. I quickly discovered that I was terrible at estimating how long a project would take. This is so common it's basically a trope in programming. Why? Because if you can describe the problems in enough detail to know how long they will take to solve, you've done most of the work of solving the problems. A corollary; much later in management I learned just how worthless interview coding questions can be. Someone who has memorized all of the "one weird tricks" for programming does not necessarily evolve into a good senior programmer over time. It works fine for the first two levels of entry programmers, who are given "tasks" or "projects" respectively. But as soon as you're past the junior levels, you're expected to work on "outcomes" or "business objectives." You're designing systems, not implementing algorithms.SWE-bench uses "issues" from Github. This sounds like it's doing things humans can't, but that fundamentally misunderstands what these issues represent. Really what it's measuring is the problems that nobody bothered allocating enough human resources to solve. If you look at the actual issue-prompts, they're are incredibly well-defined; so much so I suspect many of them were in fact written by programmers to begin with (and do not remotely resemble the type of bug reports sent to a typical B2C software company -- when's the last time your customer support email included the phrase "trailing whitespace?"). To that end, solving SWE-bench problems is a great time-saver for resource-constrained projects: it is a solution to busywork. But it doesn't mean that the LLM is "replacing" programmers...To do my job today, the AI would need to do the coding equivalent of coming up with a near perfect answer to the prompt: "research, design, and market new products for my company." The nebulous nature of the requirement is the very definition of "not being a junior engineer." It's about reasoning with trade-offs: what kind of products? Are the ideas on-brand? Is the design appealing to customers? What marketing language will work best? These are all analogous to what I do as a senior engineer, with code instead of English. Am I scared for junior devs these days? Absolutely. But I'm also hopeful. AI is saving lots of time implementing solutions which, for years now, have just been busywork to me. The hard part is knowing which algorithms to write and why, or how to describe a problem well enough that it CAN be solved. If schools/junior devs can focus more time on that, then they will become skilled senior engineers more quickly. We may need fewer programmers per project, but that just means there is more talent to start other projects IMO, freeing up intellectual resources for the high-order problems.Of course, if AGI enters the chat, then all bets are off. Once AI can reason about these complex trade-offs and make good decisions at every turn, then sure, it will replace my job... and every other job.

The first real data on AI's workplace impact just dropped, and I'm fascinated by what Anthropic's Economic Index reveals.While everyone's talking about automation and replacing jobs, 57% of AI use is actually augmentation - humans and AI working together to deliver better results. This matches what I've seen on the ground, especially in highly regulated fields like finance or fintech: AI enhances analysis but doesn't replace judgment.Most telling: AI adoption clusters in mid-to-high salary knowledge work. Senior executives and physical laborers both show minimal AI impact. This tracks - AI excels at processing information, not at either making complex strategic decisions or performing physical tasks.Here's the stat you should watch out for: Only 4% of jobs heavily use AI, but 36% are starting to experiment. We're seeing more "Microsoft Excel for knowledge work" than "robots taking jobs."Question for my finance folks: How do we value productivity gains from AI augmentation vs cost savings from automation? The data suggest we might be looking at the wrong metrics.Interested? Read more about this fascinating work here:

AI, Job Cuts, and Singapores Economic Future Whats Next?The wave of job cuts driven by Artificial Intelligence has already begun, starting with Banking, Finance, and Insuranceindustries that heavily rely on white-collar workers. As AI-driven automation becomes more sophisticated, more sectors will follow.If the US faces a recession in 2025, it will "Turbocharge" global job cuts, particularly in economies that are deeply connected to US trade, including Singapore. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) projects Singapores economic growth to be between 1% and 3%a low growth scenario combined with a US downturn would likely have a significant impact on our job market.At the same time, many retrenched workers will turn to SkillsFuture to upskill in AI-related fields. Ironically, this could accelerate even more AI-driven job replacement, leading to further disruptions. The cycle is clear: the faster we adopt AI, the faster traditional jobs become obsolete.Looking ahead, if our next-generation Singaporeans focus on AI-driven Robotics and Machine Intelligence, we may not be able to save all jobs globallybut we can certainly help our workforce transition faster into the new Industrialization era of Machine Intelligence.The key question is: How do we balance AI adoption with sustainable employment?What do you think?

I don't interpret AI Winter as a concept to have anything to do with business applications not meeting the hype surrounding them. *That* is part of the regular boom-bust cycle of the capitalist system and is present in all industries.AI Winters are those periods when for academic and industrial research it isn't clear what the next steps required to progress are and new advancements have stagnated for approximately a decade or more.For example, during the 90's AI Winter many people were experimenting with symbolic AI rather than connectionist AI because they thought the next breakthrough would be there.In the early 2010's, deep learning based image classifiers were becoming very mature and there were further advancements in neuro-symbolic narrow AI with the release of examples like AlphaGo. We also saw more interest in Adversarial Machine Learning (GANs were invented in 2014.) All of this set a continuous ground-work for further advancements in the late 2010's and early 2020's (i.e. transformers, diffusion models, alphafold, etc.) There was no discontinuity in primary research as we saw in the 70's and 90's. The practicality of deep learning created doors which have not yet all been opened.We're still in what is called the "deep learning revolution."

In the short term, true, but think about physical labor. Initially, humans toiled in fields. Then, some managed to domesticate animals like horses, and humans used them to till fields and for transport. It no longer made sense for a person to till a field. Later, engines displaced the horses. The economy didn't have a use for all of the horses it had before, and the horse population shrunk.Humans found other things they could do that animals and engines couldn't, however, because of their brains. But, if AI (and robots) do a better job than humans, I think it becomes a real question what economic work humans can actually do. Remember, someone has to be willing to pay for your work which (by the assumptions of this argument) are less efficient and less good than what AI & robots can produce. So I'm not sure I see how the current economic system is going to survive that.

If we consider that AIs will take our jobs in the future, our new role will be to make them even more capable. Large companies will pay us to do that.For example, the new roles might involve recording real-time human conversations and monitoring specific areas of the brain to further optimize AI performance 24/7. Other possibilities include dedicating ourselves full time to writing text for every situation, recording new conversations, tracking our movements, analyzing our thought patterns, and documenting our chains of thought and reasoning, all in real time and as a full-time commitment. Essentially, everything that AI currently lacks.Large companies have already been doing this, primarily collecting data from the internet and our phones, but not to their full potential. There remain elements and nuances that exist only in the real world and are not present online.Even if each person's individual contribution may seem insignificant for large companies, if too many people perform that job every day, incredible advancements for AI could be achieved. Moreover, in a scenario where AI dominates the job market, large companies might pay us simply to exist, essentially a form of universal basic income, or at least in a utopian scenario.Once these models become even smarter, a large portion of the population could become insignificant in the economy, as AI would be the most intelligent and productive entity in the world. The only real limitation of AI is its ability to operate in the physical world. For now, AI cannot perform the work of a plumber, but it is only a matter of time.Perhaps our generation will be spared from this hypothetical scenario, though it remains a possibility. Perhaps there may be new forms such as neo-feudalism, post-capitalism, etc. or some type of communism.Undoubtedly, all of this will lead to chaos, potential wars, social problems, and much more if things do not go smoothly.Obviously, this is speculation and assumptions, but I believe it is a good idea to be prepared, even if we practically cannot do anything for ourselves.Whatever happens in the future, I wish you all good luck.

**Have you noticed how AI discussions often focus on chatbots or weird image generators?** The truth is far more impactful: AI is about doing the work we typically rely on humans for**the work you cant just hand off to a basic computer program.**In other words, its about executing**Intelligence Tasks**within**Intelligence Pipelines**.# Intelligence Tasks Are EverywhereLook around at any companybig or small. Underneath all the shiny branding, every role boils down to a set of thinking tasks chained together:* **Office Work** * summarize_meeting send_summary_to_stakeholders read_report proofread_document etc.* **Programming Work** * solve_problem write_code research_better_way approve_pr etc.* **Customer Service** * read_complaint check_customer_history respond_to_customer make_customer_happy etc.* **Medical Work** * analyze_mole diagnose_disease write_prescription analyze_xray etc.* **Research** * find_sources rate_sources summarize_article extract_key_ideas write_report etc.* **Manager Work** * interview_candidate manage_budget document_program_progress deliver_presentation etc.* **Creative Work** * brainstorm riff_on_idea expand_idea write_first_draft create_art etc.These tasks**require human intelligence**until now.# Why So Few People Can Do This WorkHighly specialized tasks (think analyzing moles for cancer or parsing cybersecurity logs) are done by a tiny pool of experts. But its not just about skill scarcity. Its also about the**massive volume**of such tasks that arent being done at all, simply because there arent enough humans available.* Watching meteors (Astronomy)* Tutoring (Education)* Investigations (Journalism)* Checking fraud (Finance, Cybersecurity)* Empathic listening (Mental Health)**Billions**of people lack access to expertsteachers, doctors, nurses, therapists, investigatorsbecause these**Intelligence Tasks**take time, money, and specialized knowledge.# Measuring Intelligence Task Execution with KISACTo evaluate how well a person (or AI) performs these tasks, consider**KISAC**:1. **Knowledge** How deeply do they know the field, history, main thinkers, theories, books, etc.?2. **Intelligence** How adept are they at recognizing patterns and delivering insight?3. **Speed** How quickly can they complete tasks at a high standard?4. **Accuracy** How often do they get it right versus making mistakes?5. **Cost** How expensive is it to hire, train, and keep them doing the task?# Human vs. AI on KISAC# 1. Knowledge* **Humans**: A dedicated expert might read thousands of books in a lifetime, see a few thousand examples, and thats considered highly trained.* **AI**: Can ingest basically**all**available books, case studies, and datamaintaining perfect recall.# 2. Intelligence* **Humans**: Average IQ ~100. A rare few might reach 180, but thats extremely uncommon.* **AI**: Surpassed a childs intelligence in 2022. By 2024, its around ~100 IQ (task-dependent). Experts believe some models will reach genius-level soon. In certain narrow tasks, theyre already*beyond*human ability.# 3. Speed* **Humans**: * Checking moles: a few hundred a day * Summarizing articles: maybe 520 daily * Assessing X-Rays: 100500 daily* **AI**: * Checking moles:**millions**per day * Summarizing articles:**thousands**per day * Assessing X-Rays:**hundreds of thousands**per dayAnd thats typically**one**AI instancescale it up with more instances and you can multiply those outputs by 10x, 100x, or 1000x.# 4. Accuracy* **Humans**: Highly accurate if they work slowly, but errors (especially medical) are alarmingly common.* **AI**: * Already rivaling or surpassing doctors in diagnosing diseases or evaluating X-Rays. * Efficiency and automation mean multiple checks/validations can reduce errors further.# 5. Cost* **Humans**: * Expensive to train, maintain, retrain, and replace. * High performers demand higher salaries.* **AI**: * A fraction of the cost for most tasks. * A single upgrade to a core model instantly elevates an entire AI team. * The difference in cost between mid-level and top-level performance is negligible.# Real-World ExampleImagine a top-performing claims analyst, Carol, who processes 29 cases a day with 89% accuracy at a salary of $137,200/year. Now picture an AI that can handle**29,000**cases a day at**93% accuracy**for**$3,500/year**. That gapin both volume and costwill keep widening as AI improves.# The Big Picture: Companies Are Just Intelligence PipelinesWhen you strip away the fluff,**companies are just sequences of intelligence-based tasks**that aim for a goal. AI is getting incredibly good at these tasks:1. Faster2. More accurately3. At a fraction of the costThis has profound implications:* **Businesses that leverage AI will dominate.**Those that dont will be left behind.* **Entire pipelines once handled by humans**will soon be**mostly AI-driven**.* **AI isn't just chatbots or image generators**; its the entire knowledge workforce across industries.# Why This Matters* Most intelligence tasks on Earth arent even done right now, because we lack people-power. AI fills that gap instantly.* For the tasks we do manage, AI can do them at radically higher scale and lower cost.* **Its not about replacing humans**as much as its about unveiling an enormous new capacity for workwhere speed, accuracy, and affordability converge.**In short, AIs real revolution is quietly taking place in back offices, research labs, customer service teams, medical facilities, and countless other places**anywhere human minds were once the only option.**TL;DR:*** **AI**=**execution of Intelligence Tasks**at superhuman scale and speed.* **Companies**=**chains of these tasks**(Intelligence Pipelines).* **Future**: Those who harness AI flourish. Those who dont risk obsolescence.**So, forget the flashy demos.**The real story of AI is that its going to handle huge volumes of specialized knowledge workand do it better, faster, and cheaper than we ever thought possible.

Oh, so youre letting AI help you ace your interviews? What could possibly go wrong? (Spoiler: A LOT.) Amazon is cracking down on AI-generated answers in job interviews yes, you read that right. AI in its current form can't really replace jobs that people need to do, but can just reduce the number of people needed to do them. In the past technology has replaced specific industries, and those people could transition to something else. What is problematic is if AI is able to just replace X% of the workforce across all industries.

Just because a certain job is going to be replaced by an AI that doesn't mean that there aren't going to be job openings because of AI. There is maintenance, calibration, some small tasks that are required to be given to the AI as input, etc. Also, think about business growth. Because you need less people to do the same amount of work, you have the financial freedom to hire more people and try to expand your business. Of course, this is a short term phenomenon because not all businesses could grow (there needs to be a bit more inflation for extra spending). Imagine this. If I am a freelance writer, and I could have an AI that catches grammar and lexical errors, with 99% correctness, then I won't need to hire an editor. But I will probably hire more people so I could have more content which is going to be checked by that AI.The suggestion for using AI in medicine, etc. is also intriguing. That doesn't mean that becoming a doctor will be easy. Hard cases will become easier thanks to careful observation of symptoms. You will be able to get suggestions for treatment, based on those symptoms. Or you could get suggestions for extra clinical trials that often show vital information for a given symptom, etc.

The following submission statement was provided by /u/Gari_305:---From the article>The[AI-Generated Index of Occupational Exposure](https://publications.iadb.org/en/publications/english/viewer/Mirror-Mirror-on-the-Wall-Which-Jobs-Will-AI-Replace-After-All-A-New-Index-of-Occupational-Exposure.pdf)calculates the potential impact of artificial intelligence on occupations and their associated tasks among more than 750 professions on one, five and 10-year timelines. It is based on large data sets, which it processes and synthesizes quickly, offering an alternative to traditional surveys, which are usually expensive.>According to the index, 980 million jobs around the world will be affected in some way by this new technology within the year. That amounts to 28% of the global workforce. Within five years, that figure will rise to between 38%, and in 10 years, 44%.>Those are compelling numbers, and while they dont equate to jobs that will be necessarily lost, the fact that AI will impact nearly half of the worlds employment in some way implies that we are looking at a change of a magnitude similar to that which followed[the 19th-century industrial revolution.](https://english.elpais.com/technology/2024-04-03/author-brian-merchant-luddites-are-more-dangerous-to-the-elites-and-to-the-rich-than-robin-hood.html)This is an industrial revolution that is growing exponentially. Its going to take less time to implement. We must make adjustments quickly and thats why we are carrying out this research, to send a message of caution, says Parrado. The goal of the index is to serve as a warning, so that, instead of having negative consequences, AI will bring benefits.--- Please reply to OP's comment here: https://old.reddit.com/r/Futurology/comments/1fhriwh/artificial_intelligence_will_affect_60_million_us/lnc4lwj/

Job Board Alert: How Job Seekers are Using AI to Job Search: AI is revolutionizing the job search, but not without creating new challenges. Resume Nows new report exposes the paradox: while 84% of workers find AI makes job hunting easier, a significant 66% feel its also increased competition.Key Findings* AI Simplifies Job Searching: 84% of workers say AI has made finding job opportunities easier, with 80% using AI-powered job search platforms.* AI Tools are Widely Used in Applications: 68% of workers use AI to write resumes, and 67% use AI to craft personalized cover letters* Increased Job Competition Due to AI: 66% believe AI has significantly intensified job competition by enabling more applicants to find and apply for the same positions faster.How AI is Changing Job ApplicationsAI is becoming an essential part of the job search process. From generating tailored resumes to enhancing cover letters and preparing for interviews, AI tools are helping job seekers navigate todays competitive job market.* 68% of workers use AI to write their resumes, ensuring keyword optimization and a professional tone.* 67% use AI to craft personalized cover letters that better align with job descriptions.* 76% completely trust AI-generated job recommendations, highlighting growing confidence in AIs capabilities.Most Popular AI Tools for Job Seekers:* ChatGPT (58%)* AI-powered resume builders (52%)* AI-driven interview preparation tools (32%)* AI-based networking tools (17%)AI Increases Job CompetitionWhile AI makes job searching easier, it also raises the stakes in a competitive job market:* 66% say AI has significantly increased job competition by enabling more applicants to discover and apply for the same positions faster.* 33% believe AI has somewhat increased competition.* Only 1% report no impact from AI on job competition.Navigating the AI-Driven Job MarketThe widespread use of AI is reshaping hiring practices, including how employers screen resumes and assess candidates. As more applicants leverage AI tools to optimize their job applications, the bar for standing out continues to rise. This dynamic is driving job seekers to find new ways to differentiate themselves, such as using more creative, personalized applications or enhancing their digital presence.AI is playing an increasingly significant role in job searches, says Keith Spencer, career expert at Resume Now. Our findings show that many job seekers are using AI tools to assist with job applications, and a majority believe AI has made job searching easier. At the same time, most workers acknowledge that AI has also increased job competition. Understanding how to navigate AI-driven hiring processes can help job seekers optimize their applications and job search strategies.The future of job searching with AI is poised for significant From our job board directory.

The undeniable reality is that a significant number of individuals will need to acquire AI-related skills and actively seek ways to integrate this technology into their existing job roles and tasks. The internet revolution led to the displacement of numerous office and clerical workers, as well as unskilled positions such as delivery persons and filing clerks. For instance, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that travel agent jobs in the United States fell from around 124,000 in 2000 to approximately 64,000 in 2020, a decrease of about 60,000 jobs.The individuals who thrived during this period of technological change and maintained a competitive edge with recent college graduates were those who proactively pursued knowledge in operating systems, software applications, and ancillary tasks like typing. As an example, workers who embraced digital marketing, social media management, and web development found new opportunities and success in the job market.Similarly, in the age of AI, it is crucial for workers to adapt by acquiring new technical skills, such as data analysis, machine learning, and AI integration. By doing so, they can leverage AI to enhance their productivity, streamline their workflows, and potentially discover new, innovative ways to approach their work. As the World Economic Forum predicts that AI and automation will create 97 million new jobs by 2025, individuals who invest time and effort in upskilling and reskilling will be better positioned to succeed in this rapidly evolving landscape.--------------------------------------------------------TLDR: Learn to use AI software and systems now. Start figuring out ways you can make programs such as ChatGPT and Dalle-2 work for you in your current job. Don't be like office worker who still couldn't type or make excel spreadsheets in 2001. Also, old jobs gone; new jobs appear. No worries if you learn to use AI.

The short answer is construction jobs will probably fall, but not for the obvious reason (robots replacing humans)The longer answer:Much of the recent economic hardship in the US and Europe is fallout from the computer revolution. The computer destroyed a huge number of lower middle class jobs, which havent been replaced. These jobs were largely in production, clerical, admin, and sales:https://econofact.org/the-shrinking-share-of-middle-income-jobsProfessional, technical and managerial jobs have largely survived intact, but since 2000 these have also started to decline. AI will only accelerate this trend.Low-pay jobs, such as in construction, are growing and seem likely to survive. At the very least, AI operated robots will need very significant human intervention to work.But, if high paying jobs decline due to AI, there will be a severe knock on effect on construction. So while some construction jobs may be automated, the larger impact could be lack of people able to afford construction services (in the same way that the whole economy is suffering due to the loss of lower middle class jobs).

"AI Reduces demand for workers whose tasks can be automated."We hear this constantly, and the employment implications feel scary.But a groundbreaking 2025 study from the National Bureau of Economic Research reveals this is just one part of a 3-part story. The other parts paint a much more optimistic picture: Workers naturally shift efforts to tasks AI can't do well AI-adopting firms grow faster and hire more workers overallBottom line: Despite alarming headlines, the research shows that while AI substitutes for labor at the task level, the aggregate employment effects are surprisingly small because these three forces largely offset each other.What does this mean for HR and business leaders? To achieve the growth effects documented in the paper - increased sales (9.5%), higher employment (6%), greater profits (8.5%), and improved productivity (7.6%) - you need a comprehensive workforce strategy that breaks down work into tasks, identifies AI opportunities, and shifts skill development accordingly.Whenoftalks about the growth potential of your AI transformation, *this* is what she's talking about.

I actually work in language AI in my work. It's not my main gig, but I contribute to research on models that are similar to ChatGPT in terms of the model architecture at least (i.e. large transformers).There are two reasons why I am not particularly worried about AI taking my job (as a software engineer).The first is that AI models like ChatGPT are still pretty tightly coupled to the task they were trained to solve. Unlike our brains, they aren't capable of learning to do one thing and then applying it to learn to do something else (at least not on their own, I am aware of things like transfer learning). While ChatGPT's results are impressive, these models are far from a general intelligence or anything close to as cognizant as an actual human being. Sure, it can write code, but it absolutely cannot contemplate the trade-offs of complex architecture or build something novel and complex yet. People say it may soon, but that is not 100% given.The second is that, because of the first reason, AI is still completely incapable of (or at best very poor at) identifying problems to be solved, and that's not really the point of the AI tools we build today. Right now, AI is a tool built by humans to solve problems for humans. There will always be a demand for human experts to identify which problems are the things that those with the resources to implement AI solutions should be solving to be competitive with other firms. Software engineers today will become the people designing the problems to solve tomorrow. We do that already, but we just build the solutions manually today.

If you have 100 employees, but they all start using AI tools that drastically increase their productivity - you still need humans for it, but now 20-30 people can do the work of 100 in the same timeframe. My opinion is, that two awesome things will occur with AI. First, to your point, right now we have darn good AI, and yet, there is work everywhere. If anything, there is MORE work in the coding space now than before. How can that be so? Well just because a specific file in a code base can be written by an AI, doesnt mean that an AI can independently create a code project well at all. It requires a good human prompter and someone who can think about the codebase abstractly and many other soft skills that AI simply cant do today, if ever. Its the Luddite fallacy at work - which says just because we have new tech, that increase in using that tech actually creates more demand and thus more jobs. It is possible that the jobs change and that a programmer will be more like a pilot of a code project overseeing AI and doing less overall, but it will still be needed. 2) Lets say that AI can somehow take more of or all of the jobs. Well, in that case, it would affect all of us. Economically, nobody would be making income and thus, there would be little to no buyer base to pay for products , hence a pricing crash would occur. Also, if AI was the thing that took the job in a hypothetical utopian case, so long as we all have access to it, the barrier to use AI would be nill, and this means, that almost anyone could start a competing business really with any company (large and small anywhere). The hyper competition that wound occur with AI, alongside of nobody making any money to pay for services, would ultimately lead a a pricing crash and crash of the dollar. Artists won't lose their jobs. We won't read generated novels, listen generated music or worship paintings made by robot. In 1967, Roland Barthes challenged the idea that the author was the most important aspect of a work of art in his influential essay "The Death of the Author". Instead, he argued that the art itself and the structure in which it was created were more significant. However, in the 55 years since the essay was published, the importance of the artist has been reaffirmed in a different way.Today, we not only ask if art is made by humans but also if it's made by artificial intelligence. This question is significant because it reveals what humans value. Humans have a natural inclination to appreciate art made by other humans, and while we don't have a satisfying definition of what art is, we know that it holds social importance (even the most influential George Dickie's institutional definition is determined socially).To understand the value of human-made art, we can compare it to sports. Even though robots may be faster, more precise, and stronger, we still compare sports achievements among humans. In the same way, AI-generated art will likely have its own category that replaces some marketing aesthetics and products, such as stock photos and low-effort graphics. It may even be used as a tool for creating new forms of art.However, AI-generated art will not make human artists obsolete. People will lose interest if they realize that a particular piece of music or image was created by AI. As Denis Dutton stated in his essay "Artistic Crimes" about art forgery, a painting that is similar to the Mona Lisa may be celebrated and valued as a Da Vinci masterpiece, but if it's discovered to be a forgery, all the former glory will be gone. This is because the forger created the art in a different context, with less effort and without the same level of creativity and skill as the original artist.AI-generated art will have its own place in the art world, but it will not replace the value and appreciation of human-made art.

Patently absurd.AI is absolutely terrible at doing all the jobs we want AI to do - all the lowest paying, meanial, tedious jobs. Healthcare. Daycare. Physical labor. Dangerous jobs. This is where more than half the job market is.AI is good at all the desirable white-collar jobs. Lots of desk and clerical work. But also repetive tasks, copywriting, voiceover, other tasks. There's a lot of low hanging white-collar fruit AI is going to pluck, and already has. This was one of the fastest bubbles to blow up and pop in technology history.AI is a STUPID word for "algorithm". That's it. It's a glorified math equation. All that an AI can do is locked into that equation. That's it's bounds, it's hard limits. And the more you look at it, the more you realize just where those limits are - it's limits are not a neat little box, but this weird, inconsistent shape, with edges, and curves, blobs out in free space... And even within, there's a grain. You see it already - we already know - mathematically proven, that you can get an algorithm to generate effectively anything you want, with the right inputs.But AI cannot create anything new, only a permutation of their equation based on their inputs. LLMs are the latest fad, and so if that model was never trained on Shakespeare, then it cannot generate anything Shakespeareian. And the best it can do is garbage-in, garbage-out.I work in software, and AI has had effectively zero actual impact. Everything it can do, we already have solutions for. It can rewrite old code like what it was trained on, but we already have libraries and distribution systems for that. Engineers who reinvent old code tend not to have jobs for very long. Most of us are trying to create something new, which is exactly where AI fails us, because it can't go where we haven't already been.The software world is under a different, economic crunch, though...

The idea of AI replacing hospital staff any time within even the next 30 years is laughable. I even asked asked actual AI if that could happen. Believe me I would love it. I would feel much safer with automated care. Patients are not getting adequate care now and hospitals are chronically understaffed due to the business model and challenge to stay profitable. Having said that would be very nice to have robots on the floor that could help with manpower stuff. Anyway this is what AI said. The idea of AI replacing nurses is unrealistic. While technology like automated monitoring and medication dispensing can assist with routine tasks, nursing is far more complex. It requires physical carelike wound dressing, turning patients, lifting, and toiletingalong with emotional support, advocacy, and communication with families. Robots cant replicate empathy, human intuition, or the ability to anticipate issues like early sepsis signs. Nurses also coordinate care across departments, adjust critical drips, take orders from doctors, and manage unpredictable situations that demand quick thinking and nuanced judgment. Even with advances in AI, hospitals will still need human caregivers to provide hands-on care and relational support. Machines may handle repetitive tasks, but nursing involves far too many dynamic, human elementscompassion, trust, and clinical insightthat robots simply cant replicate. The idea of fully staffing a busy hospital floor with machines is not just impractical but decades away, if it ever becomes possible at all.

Will hashtag#AI automation be the real threat to the booming Indian Economy?Perhaps this is the question on which I have tried to read, research, and decipher a lot. Here, I have tried to express my thoughts from all the readings that I did.For decades, India has dominated the IT and BPO sectors, thriving on cost arbitrage. The formula was simple: offshore repetitive, process-driven work to India at scale. But AI is rewriting that script.So, will AI kill Indias IT-BPO industry? No.But will it restructure it? Absolutely.Heres whats happening: AI is wiping out low-end jobs.Data entry? Automated. Customer support? AI chatbots. Coding at scale? AI copilots are already replacing junior developers. The BPO model we knew is dead. BPO 2.0 isnt about cost arbitrage; its about execution arbitrage.The game is shifting from manpower to AI-first operations. Businesses wont just outsource work - theyll outsource AI-driven execution. Companies that adapt will thrive. Others? Well Indias IT giants arent sitting idle.TCS, Infosys, Wipro - they see the writing on the wall. They arent waiting to be disrupted; theyre embedding AI into their delivery models, shifting from bulk outsourcing to AI-driven transformation consulting. But heres my counterpoint:I dont buy into the India will upskill narrative. We dont upskill fast enough.For every AI engineer India produces,itself is making 10 others redundant. And thats the problem no one wants to talk about. The hard truth:Most of Indias laptop jobs - mid-tier IT services, low-end finance & legal outsourcing - will vanish. AI isnt enhancing these roles; its replacing them.So, whats the future?> India can become the AI execution layer for global businesses, managing AI workflows and ensuring human-AI collaboration.> Or, if we dont adapt fast enough, AI will simply eliminate the need for most of what India does today.For me, it is all about how easily we embrace the shift. But looking at the people around me, I believe the question should be:Are we truly ready for this shift?

The problem that I think coaststl is failing to grasp is that with all resources being already owned, and all manufacturing and extraction also plunging towards the cost of the embodied energy, then human productive capacity has nothing to work (resources are owned) with and is too inefficient to compete (as in you can't feed yourself making trinkets that can be manufactured for fractions of a cent). I've seen that people people will fall back on the 'humans will find a way' argument a lot over the past few years, and I put my heart there too, but now that I'm directly involved in the assessment of use cases and implementations I can see that the "structured" world we have build is a machine that machines run better. I think of it this way, we're the slow cogs in a massive economic machine. Each time we're removed from a process, the process goes faster and the 'machine' operates with greater efficiency. AI, give us the ability to remove hundreds of millions of slow cogs in the coming years, and most will not be put back in to other parts of the machine. Interesting example. Humanoid robots that cost 30k and work 7*24. Based just on current economics a human at 30k competing with lets say an equally capable robot starts at a disadvantage of 4:1. Because we would work for 40 hours a week, and the robot would work for 168. So, to just compete evenly, the human has to be paid $7142 per year. Of course once you automate the robotic production line that'll come down, once you automate the resource extraction, it'll come down, and model improvements will make it go faster. So, we're building our own conclusion. But the most import parts IMHO is how you move from a model where today, most people can barely afford to supply sufficient value to get by to an economy thats non stop converting producers in to consumers.

Here is how you can prepare yourself and your career for the AI revolution. Many people I speak with are overwhelmed about what is happening with AI. They are excited about the technology on the one hand, but afraid and lost in terms of how will that impact on their careers.Some feel fear and paralysed by it, so they are not trying to use simple AI tools such as ChatGPT or Google Gemini, not to mention other tools like Kling and Sora.There is a clear gap of skill and knowledge, on both sides of AI jobs demand and supply. Recruiters don't necessarily know who and how they could get relevant AI talent, and amazing engineers, PMs, and executives don't know how to prepare themselves to their AI job of the future.My framework which I use in my executive coaching practice and helping founders in my portfolio at Gescheit & Partners hiring talent is quite simple:>> Take your Job Description - for example, "Product Manager">> Add the word AI in it - for example, "AI Product Manager">> Write the desired skills and experience for the non-AI job - for example, "drafting product roadmaps" or "run user experiments".>> Write the desired skills and experiences in the AI job - for example, "drafting product roadmaps using ChatGPT, and mindmapping" or "run user experiments using Claude AI for x amount of website versions".>> Identify the skills gap and experience - for example, "building websites using Claude AI">> Define a project to help you bridge the gap - "Build 2 websites using Claude AI, publish them and ask 4 people to give you feedback"This is a tangible way to define, clarify and act on preparing yourself to be AI competent no matter if you are an (AI) Software Engineer, (AI) Product Manager and even an (AI) CEO.It's about learning and to be AI focused and centric in your growth journey.

I have seen a lot of QAnon level stuff being talked about in here. I thought since I am somewhat knowledgeable in the field I would share my prediction for the near future of AI.NONE OF WHAT I'M SAYING HERE SHOULD BE TAKEN AS GOSPEL, I could be WAY off on many points, and I do not have any insider knowledge.Here goes.​**2024: GPT-Lite** When is GPT4.5/GPT5 coming out? Hopefully I'm wrong, but I'm thinking it's not 2024. Here's my reasoning.If you're a GPT+ subscriber, there's a limit to how much you can interact with GPT4 per hour. This sucks, and nobody likes this limitation. OpenAI knows this.This is a limitation they have put in place for a good reason, they cannot keep up with demand. The OpenAI user base keeps growing, and there are, as far as I know, only three ways to stop this from being a problem.1: Stop growing. Not an option for obvious reasons.2: Buy a very large amount of new GPUs. Very expensive solution, and most likely only temporary until the problem happens again.3: Make the hardware requirement for running their models lower, allowing them to serve more customers with the same number of GPUs.Releasing a GPT4.5/GPT5 with even higher resource usage than GPT4 would be problematic. This is why I believe the next step is to lower the resource usage first, and then going for a smarter model. Yes, GPT4-turbo does this to an extent, but I think they will push this further.Plus, depending on how far they can lower the resource usage, this could open the door to offloading the processing requirement onto the consumer.Imagine if they could make a "GPT-Lite" that has near GPT4 performance, but can run on smartphone hardware. They could then sell a GPT+ subscription at reduced cost, and you, the user, does all the computing for them, and in exchange you get a personal AI in your pocket at all times, similar to Siri or "Ok google", but an actual AI instead.I'm not saying smartphone AI will happen in 2024, but I do think this is what they will be aiming for in the short/mid term.​**2025: GPT5** Once the performance requirements have been lowered, this will allow OpenAI to repurpose it's large army of GPUs to training instead of serving customers. This means that training will happen much, MUCH faster.I do not think GPT5 will be quite AGI level, but most likely a model that will be able to assimilate new information as a conversation goes, and pick up on intent and nuances, allowing more natural conversations, and less "learning how to prompt".​**2027-2034: Possible AGI** To be honest, I have no idea how close we are to proper AGI, and I'm not sure we will know when we achieve it, but my guess is somewhere in that timeframe. I will be happy to be wrong and for it to be here sooner.I do think there will be roadblocks in the way to get there, ethics will come into question, military applications will be considered, and when it does happen, it will probably be kept under wraps for a certain amount of time before we hear about it.ASI will happen possibly within a year of AGI. Once we are able to create a proper intelligence, making it smarter should not be that big of a challenge. **I could be very wrong about this**​**2027-2030: Mass job loss, very "interesting" times** Nobody will want to be the first to fire a large amount of employees to replace them with AI. Think about it.If a large corporation decides to fire 50-75% of it's employees to replace them with AI, and then they realize it was a mistake, this could easily kill the entire company.All of the fired employees will be very unlikely to want to return.New employees will be very unlikely to want to work for you, knowing they will get fired at the first opportunity.It's a terrible PR move and you look like an asshole on the world stage.This is a death sentence for even the biggest and most powerful brands. NOBODY wants to be the first to pull the trigger.HOWEVER. Once a large tech firm feels confident enough to actually do it. I'm thinking either Microsoft or Google, and they actually manage to pull it off...That's when shit hits the fan, now they have dramatically reduced their cost of operations, and ALL OTHER COMPETITORS HAVE TO FOLLOW SUIT. Not doing so means falling very far behind.When the first large corporation manages to replace 50-75% of their employees with AI, I believe it will spread like wildfire, and we could end up with literally millions of jobs being lost within the span of a few months.We're not ready for that.​**TLDR:** 2024 - Lightweight GPT, similar to GPT-4, requires much less demanding hardware to run, possible to offload the processing onto consumers, hopefully running on smartphone hardware, freeing up the GPUs for training2025 - GPT5, much smarter and better at keeping up with long conversations, not quite AGI2027-2034 - Possible AGI2028-2035 - Possible ASI (will likely happen ~1 year after AGI unless held back on purpose)2027-2030 - Mass job loss in quick succession, will be very "interesting" times

It won't happen overnight, but without some sort of major societal disruption, I believe it will come. And therefore, almost anything will someday be able to be done by AI.The technology will only continue to improve from here, and innovation will continue. Logically, what reason would there be to think AI, and robotics for the mechanical part of doing any job, won't progress to this point, eventually?

I believe that blue-collar and low to mid-level white-collar jobs will eventually disappear, while high-end white-collar positions will persist the longest. Although AI models are on the verge of surpassing the computational capacity of the human brain, this doesn't mean they will immediately replace humans in all roles. This is because the nature of their computational abilities differs significantly from ours.In computational terms,**compute**can be defined as the product of**data**and**parameters**:**Compute = Data Parameters**Currently, AI models possess**100 times more data**than humans but have**100 times fewer parameters**, meaning they effectively have less computational power or "brain size" compared to us. This discrepancy explains why AI behaves differently: they have vast amounts of knowledge but lack the complex processing capabilities of the human brain.Imagine a being with a mouse-sized brain but immense memory, living an extraordinarily rich and diverse life for 400 years. Such a being would know a great deal but could never achieve the cognitive breakthroughs of an Einstein. This analogy encapsulates the current state of AI.Companies tend to focus on expanding data rather than increasing parameters because training on data is more cost-effective, and increasing parameters also raises inference costs. As a result, the trend of prioritizing data over parameters is likely to continue.However, due to the exponential growth in computational power, it's plausible that we will eventually develop AI with a "brain size" comparable to humans. I'm planning to create a**parameters vs. time graph**to estimate when such human-sized AI brains might emerge. By that time, AI will have approximately**10,000 times more data**than humans, effectively becoming like an Einstein who has lived 10,000 extremely rich and diverse lives.Until we reach that point, AI will continue to become superhuman in certain aspects while remaining subpar in others. I predict that jobs requiring high memorization skills, including physical labour, will be the first to be automated. In contrast, roles that demand complex cognitive abilities will persist longer. The duration for which high-end white-collar jobs will dominate depends on future developments, which we can better understand through the forthcoming graph.

"AI is revolutionizing recruitment"I was scrolling through TikTok recently and came across a video discussing the growing role of AI in recruitment. While AI certainly offers incredible benefits, such as speeding up the screening process, it got me thinking: Are we overlooking something critical?The video highlighted how many qualified candidates are getting automatically rejected by AI-powered systems due to overly rigid screening functions. These systems might not fully capture a candidate's potential, missing out on those who could be a perfect fit for the role but dont quite meet the keyword-heavy criteria set by the algorithm.This is where recruiters continue to be absolutely fundamental to the process. While AI can help us sort through massive pools of applicants, its the human touch that ensures no good candidate falls through the cracks. We bring context, understanding, and a level of empathy that technology just cant replace.At the end of the day, AI is a tool, but its the recruiters expertise and intuition that really connects the dots and builds the most successful teams.

Heres my take:In the short term, I would say that if you can work from home then your job will be one of the first to go.Skilled jobs that require you to work with your hands, will have a better shelf life but these too will become automated in time (unless something major holds back the current rate of progress!).My mind isnt made up yet regarding jobs like surgeons etc. Perhaps itll be like self-driving vehicles, which will (if theyre not already) be far safer than any human but for some reason wed (currently at least) rather put our life in the hands of other humans rather than the robotsThe latest progress in AI shows me that all jobs can and will be replaced (many people would have argued that AI will never be able to produce art, for instance, but I think we can now see that this is false).People always say that we will still need humans to oversee processes and that we will find new jobs that have not yet even been imagined of, but I dont believe that this is true in the way it was with previous technological advances.Advances in agricultural technology meant that our collective physical strength was no longer required, so we moved to more intellectual jobs. Advances in AI will mean that our intellectual strength is no longer required. Perhaps the only thing that will remain of our usefulness is human compassion?For this reason I see carers and teachers being something that people still want done by other humans. Or perhaps we should be thinking about jobs that arent currently values by the economic system, such as caring for children and looking after elderly family etc. That said I feel like we need to rediscover this side of us, as I believe the prevailing culture has left us disconnected from one another.If we can work out how to redistribute the benefits that technology provide (yes I believe that UBI is the only solution to this..), then I see little reason why most people would need to go to work at all. It has the potential to free us up for a much more meaningful life and we should be celebrating our imminent redundancy not fearing it!We will need to adjust though, as many people derive a sense of purpose from their work and will take some time to find a new sense of purpose without itThat said, why has our increased productivity up until now not resulted in the level of freedom it promised? I suspect its, in part, because if you can keep people in the rat race then they are much easier to control by those with power? The most advanced intelligence will still likely be held by those with money and power, but hopefully the level of technology available to the average person will allow them independence from the systems that give that power away in the first place.

Sitting in a meeting today, discussing the financial state of a very large corporation I work for one man asked to address the board. "Very simply" he said, "we're approaching a time when staff are legitimately replaced by robots, I think it's time we start downgrading our (skilled) staff into low-mid range positions since so many of their past functions are being replaced by computers." So began discussion on fusing the low level positions with the low mid range positions with a significant pay cut for the latter. I was both excited and appalled that these hard-working employees were going to effectively be demoted just for using computers for part of their job. It's all just further proof that computers don't free up more time for the worker, they just make it so corporations can pay less for the same amount of work. Feel free to give your thoughts, I can't say which organization I work for, but figured this sub would like to hear of it.

Hey. Thanks for those links. Extremely interestingMy point is to look on disruption in terms of timing and psychological factors. Timing. It will take time. Question is how much time it will take. So will restaurants be disrupted in 50 years - sure. Will restaurants be disrupted in this decade - Im not that optimistic. Some repetitive stuff - probably. But not all. Second factor is psychological or lets call it human factor. I really like example of chess. We have right now boom in chess popularity even though computers are better in chess for almost a decade. Chess bots are much better. Their strategies are awesome and very unique, sometimes absolutely illogical for human. Still we mostly enjoy human competition, as machines and their played are soulless. Chess bots have transformed into the tool that most chess players use and we become better players thanks to them. I believe same will happen with many spheres nearest decade. Many repetitive non physical job will be disrupted. Question is -> will AI lead to substantial economical growth. If yes (taking into account declining population) everything will be alright with job market. Each company will require much less accountants but overall job market will grow.If we are lucky maybe it will lead to lower amount of work we need to do (look at what happens in Europe with 4 day week) so we will have more time as society for leisure, art and science.Moreover we can speculate that another trend will occur. As margins on different products will go up due to decreased costs the amount of investment capital will increase which might lead to new boom of investment. If we put those newly available money into science - well everything will be alright.Of course all of these do not take into account creation of scalable AGI. This will be critical technological breakthrough and it is very difficult to speculate on future.

About 20 years ago, there was a major breakthrough in AI which has led to a number of other breakthroughs. The main effect was that AI research which had been stuck for some time was able to advance.Lately, we are seeing generative AI which can be used for text generation, image generation, something like reasoning, and critically text and image/video/audio understanding.A lot of the current hype stuff relevant to office workers is around text and ideas expressed in text. There has been a lot of progress and it is possible lots of office jobs will be changed or displaced.However, the same technologies do enable a robot to understand the scene it is seeing, make predictions about what will happen next, and 'think' about what to do in a more sophisticated way. This enables robots to function in a less controlled environment with less supervision than has been the case.There have also been advances in robotics. Drones have improved a lot, and you can see the kind of robots that Boston Dynamics can make on youtube.Fire fighting is a high risk activity, requiring navigating in very difficult environments, making life or death judgement. You need to work fast.I think you could see increased use of robots where it reduces risk, in the same way the bomb squad currently use robots. Maybe you could start an operation in a large building by releasing a drone swarm that would provide you with a map of the building and locate any very obvious humans. Maybe you will carry a small robot which you release to do particularly high risk things. If we do really well, maybe a walking robot will carry heavy things for you.But I don't think robots are going to replace firefighters in your career. Even after a decade of advance, they will not be trusted to make life and death decisions, and will not have advanced enough to navigate difficult terrain like a house full of trash quickly enough. Hardware advances a lot slower than software.
I think it's all about how we adapt to these changes. I believe it can create new jobs that we haven't even imagined yet.

>I always strike a lot of nerves when saying it but it's the truth. I've never met people in positions that were so displaceable where they were so oblivious and ignorant to what's happening while beingvso close to the culprit.This is quite the bold statement. Two things to consider:First, if you worked as a SWE, you should know that the current tools simply are not able to replace humans yet, not even close. They would need at least a couple of major leaps in capability to do so. Anything beyond trivial, isolated problems needs to be reviewed and fixed (if it can do them at all). Thus, requiring as much knowledge (and often as much time) to finish the work.So the question then becomes "how long will it take to improve enough?", which leads to the second point. If you now work in AI, I hope you're aware of the history. Breakthroughs and plateaus have been the story of the field for decades. No one knows when the new breakthroughs will come, maybe "*this time will be different!"*, but the historical pattern is that it will take some time for the next major innovation to get around the seemingly-inherent limitations in LLMs.People really underestimated the challenge of transferring to real-world uses. We had robots driving around obstacles and pouring beers *decades* ago. Why have robotics barely broken out of being used only in highly-engineered environments? Real world complications and context is far harder to deal with than people give credit. To actually replace SWEs, AI will have to deal with that.Eventually it will get there, but the idea it is right around the corner is cope.

Depends on what you consider to be evidence.Like I said, I've done a very deep dive into this stuff, and the opinions of the smartest, most informed people on this topic vary wildly. Depending on your level of involvement and pre-existing biases, there may not be any "evidence" that will sway you from one camp to another. At the end of the day, this is all forecasting. And humans are notoriously terrible at forecasting.However, I can certainly share some of my research that bolsters the camp 3 view. OpenAI's research claims that 19% of jobs in the US have at least a 50% exposure to automation: [https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.10130.pdf](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.10130.pdf)Accenture argues that 40% of ALL tasks across ALL industries are at high risk for complete automation ([https://www.accenture.com/content/dam/accenture/final/accenture-com/document/Accenture-A-New-Era-of-Generative-AI-for-Everyone.pdf#zoom=40](https://www.accenture.com/content/dam/accenture/final/accenture-com/document/Accenture-A-New-Era-of-Generative-AI-for-Everyone.pdf#zoom=40)). McKinsey claims that *today's* gen AI can, in practice. automate tasks that account for about 60 - 70% labor hours. They also estimate that 50% of current work will be automated as early as 2030 ([https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-economic-potential-of-generative-ai-the-next-productivity-frontier#key-insights](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-economic-potential-of-generative-ai-the-next-productivity-frontier#key-insights)). They also argue that the productivity gains (and labor cost reduction impacts) of gen AI will amount to $2.4T+ annually. Lastly, although the WEF doesn't produce any of its own research on the topic -- they have published several articles on job displacement and generative AI, claiming that we are on the brink of the fourth industrial revolution.If you view the conservative estimates from any of these organizations as remotely possible, then it's difficult to see how camp 3 is incorrect.I'd also add that, if you're building any B2B gen AI solutions right now, or are even tangentially involved in the space -- you'd have a very hard time disagreeing with camp 3. Give it 3 - 6 months for some of these tools to start coming out -- and you might start to see the writing on the wall.

As someone with a PhD in AI/ML and having worked in top tech firms, I can confidently say that AI won't replace developers - it'll transform how they work, making them more efficient and productive.Think of AI as a powerful IDE on steroids. This actually makes them more valuable, not less.The key is to embrace AI as a tool that enhances your capabilities rather than viewing it as a threat. AI and automation can change many tasks that are repetitive, risky, or need to analyze large amounts of data faster than humans can. This isn't new - technology has altered work for centuries. The aim is usually not to eliminate jobs completely, but to improve efficiency, safety, and productivity.The idea of AI replacing jobs can cause worry about unemployment and outdated skills. While some jobs might decline, new ones often appear, like managing or collaborating with AI. This may need a shift in learning and training. AI can take over dangerous tasks and leave humans more time for creative, strategic, and social activities.This change goes beyond jobs; it affects how we see work, education, and adaptability in a rapidly changing world. Societies may need to change education and continuous learning to adjust to working with AI. There are ethical issues too, such as making sure AI benefits everyone and serves the public good.In my view, AI has great potential to solve complex issues, from healthcare to the environment. But it's important to carefully consider its ethical effects, social equity, and human impact as it's developed and used. The aim should be to enhance human abilities and improve life quality, not just replace jobs.
