Last week, Klarna, a Swedish fintech company, announced it had paused hiring because AI could do most of its jobs. Do you think AI can do the work of its 700 customer service workers?Based on what I have seen, its feasible. However, would you trust AI to manage financial transactions and decide who to extend credit to? As AI breezes past our benchmarks, is it ready to take on more roles?Gemini can ace the Bar Exam but isnt a competent lawyer. ChatGPT can solve LeetCode challenges and pass software engineer interviews but isnt capable of coding solutions independently.GenAI is showing how weak our assessment tools are. They advance the most primitive types of intelligence to the front of the line without evaluating more complex, higher-value capabilities.Theres a cottage industry that prepares candidates to interview for tech jobs and pass tests because the capabilities required to do the job successfully differ from those required to get hired.Researchers have been identifying gaps for decades, but were only now building more accurate assessments in response to AIs progress. Business leaders and academia should take note.CEOs who look at AI through the lens of narrow benchmarks and demos will replace people with platforms that arent up to the job.Companies that hire based on weak assessment tools will be staffed by replaceable workers, not the future capabilities they need to remain competitive.Universities that admit based on standardized test scores and teach students to pass surface-level capabilities assessments prepare students for jobs that will not exist when they graduate.Businesses and academia must get in front of this trend. Most courses are obsolete. Curricula must be realigned with the future of work, not the easily automated skills of the past.The number of obsolete jobs is growing. Hiring must look past the AI replacement cycle to bring in the resilient capabilities the business needs to survive.If we dont adapt, well have a generation of businesses and workers who cant compete in the AI marketplace.

Will AI Replace Human Jobs or Create More Opportunities? AI is transforming industries at an unprecedented pace. From automating repetitive tasks to generating high-quality content, technology is evolving faster than ever. But heres the big question:Will AI take over jobs, or will it open doors to new career opportunities?Some argue that AI will eliminate millions of jobs, especially in customer service, content creation, and administrative roles. Others believe it will enhance productivity and create new job categories we havent even imagined yet! My thoughts? AI isnt here to replace humansits here to assist us. The key is adaptation. Those who learn how to leverage AI tools will thrive, while those who resist change may struggle. What do you think? Will AI be a job killer or a job creator? Lets discuss!

You raised some pertinent points regarding AI's effect on the job market. While AI and automation are certainly going to change many industries, the idea that they're going to kill all jobs is just way too simplistic.First, AI tends to excel in tasks of a repetitive and data-driven nature. As much as this is going to displace certain jobs, it also opens up opportunities for new roles that tend to leverage human creativity, critical thinking, and emotional intelligencevery hard attributes to replicate in AI. For example, the new fields emerging are those related to AI oversight, ethical governance, and human-AI collaboration.Second, not everyone either desires or needs a college degree for employment with meaning. Practical skills, especially those involving physical tasks like plumbing and auto mechanics, are far less likely to be automated anytime soon. These jobs call for problem-solving that's complex and expertise of a hands-on naturethe kind of stuff AI still has a very hard time doing.The timeline for sweeping job displacement by AI is also unknown. Some believe this change could take place in 2035 or 2040. Others find this shift will be gradual and slow. The speed at which this happens is entirely dependent on technological advancement, economic policies, and societal adaptation.Attention needs to be focused on resilient community building, adjusting to new realities. Research into sustainable living patterns and local economies shall help in cushioning uncertainty with AI-driven changes. Preparing to coexist with AI will ensure that benefits from technological development are well-spread.Though difficult, it's not all bad. If we stay informed and are able to adjust ourselves, that should be enough to steer ourselves through these transitions and find new opportunities in the emerging job market.

**Understanding the Current Situation**A lot of people are worried about chat GPT, Bard, Llama, and all the other large language models taking their jobs. But they haven't really considered the underlying issues that have led to today's situation. Here i'm going to walk through those issues and problems and use that to project what the future of the industry might look like, regardless of automation and large language models. **The Effects of Company Cuts and Migration to IT**Last year, we saw significant cuts from large companies like Google, Amazon, and Facebook, leading to a loss of employees. The finance sector experienced hiring freezes, yet we witnessed one of the largest migrations of talent into the IT industry.On top of that the UK IT industry has been growing 10% year on year, and the [World Economic Forum](https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/01/reskilling-revolution-jobs-future-skills/) states that the world needs to reskill a billion people into IT to maintain our current pace.I enjoy mentoring in tech and usually have at least 3 or 4 people im working with at any one time, and half of them are coming over to IT from their existing job. Re-skilling and investing their time in coding, architecture and infrastructure automation.## Questions to ConsiderWith these changes, ask yourself:1. What happens when a large volume of people from different industries moves into one industry, all with the same skill set?2. How will the supply and demand challenges we have today project forward as the currently undersupplied area fills up with people?3. How are business and thought leaders responding to these changes today, and how will they respond in the future?## The Misconception of Supply and the Future of TalentMost people think that the issue is a lack of talent, and while it's true that large companies struggle to find the right talent, we're not considering what happens tomorrow. The markets are already responding to minimize the impacts of the talent shortage.Automation with chat GPT, Bard, and others will happen, but even without it, there are business mechanisms that replace multiple people with one.This contrasts starkly with the outsourcing practices of 25 years ago when one person would be replaced by 15.Market forces drive the strategies of today, which in turn impact the landscape of tomorrow.## The Potential Future ModelIn the future, we might see a team of one or two super senior people overseeing automation and business processes, similar to how a single employee supervises several self-checkout machines at a grocery store. This model could become more prevalent in the future.But again, even if it isnt automated this way, it would be reduced in some other way, it would be risky to assume there will always be an abundance of say web developer roles.## Opportunities in the Changing LandscapeAs things move forward, regardless of automation or business processes, they will simplify the systems in place, but things wont just stop. We wont pat each other on the back and say, job done. Scope and requirements never end, they just expand to cover new domains, the challenge will be spotting what those domains might look like.For AI alone, here is a starter for 10:1. AI Ethics and Compliance Officer: Ensuring AI systems adhere to ethical guidelines and comply with legal regulations.2. AI Model Auditor: Reviewing and auditing AI models to ensure their accuracy, fairness, and reliability.3. AI Data Curator: Organizing, labeling, and maintaining large datasets used for training AI models.4. AI Trainer: Teaching AI systems to perform specific tasks, including fine-tuning and improving their understanding of human language.5. Human-AI Interaction Designer: Designing and optimizing interfaces between humans and AI systems to ensure seamless and efficient communication.6. AI Explainability Specialist: Helping users understand how AI systems make decisions and predictions by providing clear explanations and visualizations.7. AI Security Specialist: Protecting AI systems from malicious attacks and ensuring the privacy of user data.8. AI Integration Consultant: Assisting businesses in integrating AI solutions into their existing workflows and processes.9. AI Policy Advisor: Guiding governments and organizations in developing policies and regulations related to AI usage and implementation.10. AI-powered Application Developer: Building and maintaining applications that leverage AI technologies to enhance user experiences and solve complex problems.My advice is get ahead of the curve, look at the problems of tomorrow and expand your mind to think outside the box in terms of what potential new areas of work could open up.If you think this is worth discussing further let me know in the comments and I can make a post on more speculative jobs and what they might look like. Most current chatbots don't use a llm or at least a very primitive one, but a locally integrated GPT or llama engine that gets regular updates with a local business knowledge base would save a ton of money. There are about 3 million customer service jobs in the united states alone, which presents an opportunity of currently about 135 billion dollars a year in potential savings. This is just employee salary alone, but there are a whole breadth of expenses estimated around 200 billion total if you include taxes, health premiums etc that will be saved. One company alone, Charter communications, has about 100000 employees, and at about 45k a year salary on average, we're looking at about a savings of 1 billion alone estimating 20000 customer service employees. Fine tuning a LLM to work specifically for the company shouldn't cost more than 10 million a year plus the cost of GPUs if they are hosting it locally or the rental cost from a cloud service keeping everything up to date and functioning properly. Eventually you will have the LLM connect to a voice model that is indistinguishable from a real live person, even able to have small talk and conversations with the caller if the caller chooses to engage. This saves charter about a billion dollars a year in savings, and they will have a much more capable employee than a lot of current ones that work there. I ran some numbers through chatgpt and at about 3 cents per interaction (estimated by the software) would be about 17 million a year in costs although I found that current cost per 1000 tokens on chatgpt is one fifth of one penny, so reduce those costs by 1/15th and you're at about 2 million a year to essentially replace a 1 billion dollar cost to your company.The great thing is even though it eliminates jobs, customer service can be very taxing with difficult customers (did it for 5 years), and AI can handle that with ease. Some company very soon is going to have a multiple dialect text to speech model that will simulate voice very well, until then this can replace all chat agents globally as well. This would all likely be powered by Nvidia chips. I could see most companies go with a cloud solution at first and slowly integrate it into their service as they see the cost savings, and eventually if they see the cost savings model go with a locally hosted version and pay for as many racks of B100 or B200 chips as it would take to meet demand. Most large corporations will probably shift fully over from human agents to AI based over the next 5 years. They could even use their best customer service agents as training data (if they even need to train, there will probably be models for customer service agents available that get licensed out).​Programs like CHAT with RTX already show how simple it is for a single person to get input based on data of pdf and text files. inputting a location on your computer you can already run your own local version of customer service employee (at least for knowledge questions). The biggest hurdle is getting it to interface with the current software and get it to perform actions on accounts.
Solution is to embrace AI and robotics to take every single job & the start beating the UBI drum.

AI Wont Save the EconomyUnless We Make It Work for EveryoneTheres a lot of hype around AI driving productivity and economic growth. But what if were getting it wrong?Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu just dropped a game-changing paper on AIs real economic impact. His research makes it clear: AI wont automatically create prosperityit depends on how we use it.Here are five stats that should make every leader pay attention: 50% of productivity gains from AI could end up concentrated in just a handful of companies. Only 0.4% of businesses in the US have adopted AI in a meaningful wayso the gap is growing. Wages could drop by up to 10% in industries that replace workers with AI, rather than augment them. Less than 10% of AI R&D is focused on human augmentationmost is geared towards automation. Inequality could spike if AI adoption follows the same pattern as past tech revolutions.The takeaway? AIs economic impact isnt written in stoneits shaped by decisions we make today.If we treat AI as a workforce multiplier instead of a cost-cutting machine, well see stronger businesses, better wages, and a more resilient economy.So how do we steer AI in the right direction? Governments, business leaders, and AI developers need to collaborate on policies, incentives, and strategies that drive broad-based valuenot just efficiency gains.Would love to hear your takehow is AI changing your industry? Ive been thinking about venturing into something new, and after much consideration, Ive decided to dedicate myself to mastering AI and related fields. This will include formal education through a masters degree, self-study, hands-on projects, and other relevant experiences.Time Commitment: I'll dive in full-time, meaning no distractions. Ill be cutting out dating and any significant social commitments for this period.Daily Schedule: Ill stick to a very structured routine that includes a set food schedule (same meals every week), planned study sessions, and consistent hours for both practical and theoretical work.Housing & Finances: Im fortunate enough to be able to sustain myself with my current housing payments, which means I can focus entirely on this without worrying too much about day-to-day financial survival. Yes, Ill lose a pension by stepping away from my current career, but Im confident I can make that up through the opportunities AI will provide.The Learning ProcessThe goal is not just to amass hours but to truly master everything AI-related. This will include:1. Formal Education: Ill pursue a Masters degree in a relevant AI or machine learning field, which will give me both structure and credibility.2. Self-Study: This will involve online courses, research papers, coding exercises, and exploring AIs applications in various industries.3. Hands-On Projects: I will build real-world projects to showcase my understanding of the field.4. Networking & Mentorship: Ill be reaching out to experts, attending conferences (virtually or in person), and staying plugged into the AI community to stay updated on trends and get feedback on my work.Endgame: High-Paying AI JobBy the time I complete this, Ill have built a high-level resume, showcasing the projects Ive completed and the deep knowledge Ive gained. My goal is to land a high-paying job in AI, machine learning, or a related field, applying everything Ive learned in an impactful way.Im documenting the whole journey, sharing updates on my progress, and possibly offering advice or resources to others who are considering a similar shift. AI: Actually making things better, or just moving the same headaches around?Steven and I attended this months AI GTM Exchange, where a group of GTM leaders had an open (and refreshingly unscripted) chat about whats really happening with AI adoption. No fluffjust straight talk on whats working and whats not.Some big takeaways:1 The AI workforce gamble Some businesses are already making bold claims about AI replacing jobs, but is that a smart bet? AI isnt a magic fixit often just shifts the problems somewhere else.2 Hype vs. reality AI has massive potential, but integrating it into existing systems is proving harder than many expected. The tools are advancing fast, but so are the challenges they create.3 AIs price tag The cost of AI is still a major barrier. With some businesses struggling to justify the spend, could this push tech pricing towards outcome-based models rather than the usual subscriptions?4 Adoption is stalling AI is everywhere, but full-scale adoption? Not so much. One reason: no ones training teams on how to actually use it. Maybe its time for an AI Enablement Officer to help businesses get real value from AI instead of just experimenting with it.Big shoutout tofor hosting and to everyone who joined the discussion! Thanks again toandfor facilitating.What do you reckonare businesses truly getting ahead with AI, or just hoping for the best?

**Yin Wang: Automatic programming is impossible. Why do I not care about artificial intelligence?**Some people have heard that I want to start a business and have suggested some ideas to fudge the mass. They said that since you are a programming language expert and now artificial intelligence (AI) is very hot, you can actually create an "automatic programming system", claiming to automatically generate programs, replace the programmer's work, and save a lot of Labor expenditure, so that you can pull investments in the "AI rush."Someone even gave me its name, "DeepCoder ( = Deep Learning + Coder)". The slogan is: "With DeepCoder, there's no need for Top Coder!" Others have pointed out the latest research being bombastically bragged about in this direction, such as Microsoft's Robust Fill...I would thank these people for their concern, but I don't care or feel optimistic about artificial intelligence. Now let me briefly talk about my opinions.***Machine-like heart***Many people like to advocate artificial intelligence, automatic cars, robots and other technologies, but if you look closely, you will find that not only these people do not understand what human intelligence is, or what the limitations of artificial intelligence are, but also the hearts of these "AI men" have been seriously mechanized. They have lost their humanity more or less as if they have forgotten that they are human, forgotten what human need most, and forgotten the value of the human. These people are like what Chaplin pointed out in the final speech of the "Great Dictator": "A machine-like person, a machine-like heart."Whenever AI is mentioned, these people must be ambitiously claiming to replace human work and save labor costs. For the time being, we will not discuss whether these goals can be achieved, but they and my values are completely contradictory from the beginning. A great company should create real new value for society, instead of trying to save any labor costs and making people unemployed! It makes me feel terrible even to think about it that I create a company whose biggest contributions are to let thousands of people lose their jobs, save labor spending for insatiable people, increase the polarization between rich and poor, concentrate power in the hands of a very small number of people and in the end, make the people unable to make their life, leading to the desolation and even collapse of society...I can't imagine living in such a world, and even if it would make me the richest person in the world, it doesn't make sense. There are too many things in the world that can't be exchanged using the money. If I walk on the street and can't see people's happy smiles or leisurely paces, no cordial greetings, cares, or humors, and no sweet romantic love, but only see the homeless all over the place overwhelmed with pains, the stinking urinary smell they left behind goes into my nostrils, and wherever I go, I'm worried about being robbed, because people have no other way to live beside stealing and robbing...If artificial intelligence succeeds, this may be the final result. Fortunately, there is plenty of evidence that artificial intelligence is never going to be successful.***My artificial intelligence dream***Many people may not know that I used to be an "AI fanatic." I have also been crazy about artificial intelligence, and deemed it as my "great ideal." I also used to comment on "human beings" at every turn, as if the machine can be compared with human beings, or even higher than human beings. When Dark Blue defeated Kasparov, I once marveled: "Oh, comes the doom of us human beings!" I also thought that once there are two magic weapons (Oh, I'm joking. They're actually two slogans): "logic" and "learning", the machine will surpass human intelligence sooner or later. However, I did not figure out how this should be achieved, nor did I figure out the meanings for achieving this.The story begins more than a decade ago when artificial intelligence was in its winter. At the library of Tsinghua University, I stumbled upon a long-lost Peter Norvig's masterpiece, Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming (PAIP). Like an archaeologist, I began to ponder and implement the various classic AI algorithms. PAIP's algorithm focuses on logic and reasoning, because in its age, many AI researchers thought human intelligence, in the final analysis, is logical reasoning. They naively believe that with things like predicate logic, first-order logic, with abilities to express "cause - result", "not only - but also", what "exists", and what is "for all", the machines can have intelligence. So they designed a variety of logic-based algorithms, expert systems, and even designed the logic-based programming language Prolog, calling it "the fifth generation programming language." In the end, they encountered insurmountable obstacles. Many AI companies could not achieve their boasted goals. Various "neuron-based" machines could not solve practical problems. Huge government and private investment were lost. Artificial intelligence entered its winter.I met PAIP in that winter. Although it didn't make me dedicated to the field of artificial intelligence, it made me fall in love with Lisp and programming language. It is also because of this book that for the first time I implemented the A* and other algorithms easily and in a structured way, and understood the true meaning of them. Also because of PAIP, I first understood what the "modularity" of a program is. I started using small "tool functions" in my own program instead of worrying about the "function call overhead" that many people are worried about. The two books, PAIP and SICP, led me to devote to the field of programming languages and be fortunate enough to get the guidance of the originators in this field.After PAIP, I was lost in machine learning for a while, because someone told me that machine learning is a new chapter in artificial intelligence. However, I gradually realized that the so-called artificial intelligence and machine learning have little to do with true human intelligence. As for the actual problems, the classic algorithm in PAIP is quite naive and complicated, and it is impossible to solve large-scale practical problems. The most important problem is that I don't see the algorithm in PAIP has anything to do with "intelligent". The term "machine learning" is completely nominal. As many people have found out, machine learning is, to be honest, just the "fit function" in statistics, replaced by a deceptive name.

From the article>The[AI-Generated Index of Occupational Exposure](https://publications.iadb.org/en/publications/english/viewer/Mirror-Mirror-on-the-Wall-Which-Jobs-Will-AI-Replace-After-All-A-New-Index-of-Occupational-Exposure.pdf)calculates the potential impact of artificial intelligence on occupations and their associated tasks among more than 750 professions on one, five and 10-year timelines. It is based on large data sets, which it processes and synthesizes quickly, offering an alternative to traditional surveys, which are usually expensive.>According to the index, 980 million jobs around the world will be affected in some way by this new technology within the year. That amounts to 28% of the global workforce. Within five years, that figure will rise to between 38%, and in 10 years, 44%.>Those are compelling numbers, and while they dont equate to jobs that will be necessarily lost, the fact that AI will impact nearly half of the worlds employment in some way implies that we are looking at a change of a magnitude similar to that which followed[the 19th-century industrial revolution.](https://english.elpais.com/technology/2024-04-03/author-brian-merchant-luddites-are-more-dangerous-to-the-elites-and-to-the-rich-than-robin-hood.html)This is an industrial revolution that is growing exponentially. Its going to take less time to implement. We must make adjustments quickly and thats why we are carrying out this research, to send a message of caution, says Parrado. The goal of the index is to serve as a warning, so that, instead of having negative consequences, AI will bring benefits.

People seem totally confused about why some specific category of jobs exists versus why jobs exist in general.Specific category of jobs: exists because there is a present need for a specific task in the very complex network of resource exchanges that we call economy.Jobs in general: exist because there is human desire to have products and services. As long as there is no ceiling to the amount and variety of things and services that humans want, you will not run out of jobs, and because humans desire interactions with other humans, you will not run out of jobs simply because machines are smarter. If that were actually the case, only engineers and scientists will have jobs in our modern world, and OnlyFans models would be on the streets in stead of in Lamborghini's. The real problem is not that jobs will go away, but the intermediate period when workers displaced by machines fail to find new jobs and instead turn to disastrous idiologies and newly machine empowered humans use their new powers in catastrophic ways. WWI, WWII, the Cold War, fascism and communism were all partly the products of the industrial revolution.

Can AI really automate our jobs?That seems to be the big question for most people when it comes to AI.Well, new interesting research has tried to answer this. It tested seven LLMs: Claude, GPT-4, Gemini, Amazon Nova, Meta Llama, and Alibaba Qwen.Their goal was to see how well the models could complete real world tasks and real world companies.They gave the AIs 175 different tasks you'd find in a typical workplace.Things like: Writing and fixing code Managing team projects Dealing with HR stuff Handling company financesHere is a summary of the results: The best-performing AI was Claude 3.5 Sonnet. Despite it being the best, Claude could complete 24% of its tasks. Each task relatively expensive, costing about $6.34 in computing power. The AI often needed around 30 attempts to figure things out. Other models, like GPT-4o took fewer steps, but their success rate was quite low (~14 steps). AI agents did best with technical stuff like coding. But struggled with things that required common sense and social skills. Sometimes the AIs would make up solutions instead of solving the problem.So what does this mean?As of today, AI is nowhere near ready to replace human workers.

The cotton gin only processes cotton. It doesn't sow, or harvest, or transport.The tractor has a host of uses, but is limited entirely to things that can be done by driving. It doesn't process, or package, or sell.A dishwasher washes dishes, but it doesn't make them, or cook the food, or set the table.___The AI replaces the job, which opens up labor for other jobs... but the AI *does those jobs too*. No amount of new jobs can open up that can't *also* be done by a sufficiently advanced robotic intelligence.AI is the technological game-changer. It's not like inventing a tool; it's like inventing a *child*. Eventually parents age out of the labor pool and their children take over. This is the reality of what we're discussing here.In the past, the elderly were so povert that we had to resort to implementing Social Security to protect them. What will we do when we're all obsolete to the labor pool, I wonder?
